title: Samoan crisis
text:
The Samoan Crisis was a standoff between the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, the <a href="German%20Empire">German Empire</a>, and the <a href="British%20Empire">British Empire</a> from 1887 to 1889 over control of the <a href="Samoan%20Islands">Samoan Islands</a> during the <a href="First%20Samoan%20Civil%20War">First Samoan Civil War</a>.
Background.
In 1878, the United States acquired a <a href="fuelling%20station">fuelling station</a> at the harbor at <a href="Pago%20Pago">Pago Pago</a>, on the island of <a href="Tutuila">Tutuila</a>, in exchange for providing guarantees of protection to Samoa. The German Empire on the other hand desired concessions at the harbor at <a href="Apia">Apia</a>, on the island of <a href="Upolu">Upolu</a>.
Incident.
The incident involved three <a href="US%20Navy">US Navy</a> warships (the <a href="sloop-of-war">sloop-of-war</a> , the <a href="screw%20steamer">screw steamer</a> , and the <a href="gunboat">gunboat</a> ) and three German warships (the gunboats and and the <a href="corvette">corvette</a> ), which kept each other at bay over several months in <a href="Apia">Apia</a> Harbour, which was monitored by the British corvette .
The standoff ended when the <a href="1889%20Apia%20cyclone">1889 Apia cyclone</a>, on 15 and 16 March, wrecked all six warships in the harbour. "Calliope" escaped the harbour and thus survived the storm. <a href="Robert%20Louis%20Stevenson">Robert Louis Stevenson</a> did not witness the storm and its aftermath at Apia but after December 1889 arrival to Samoa, he wrote about the event. The <a href="Second%20Samoan%20Civil%20War">Second Samoan Civil War</a>, involving Germany, the United States, and Britain, eventually resulted in the <a href="Tripartite%20Convention%20%281899%29">Tripartite Convention of 1899</a>, which partitioned the Samoan Islands into <a href="American%20Samoa">American Samoa</a> and <a href="German%20Samoa">German Samoa</a>.
Legacy.
<a href="Walter%20LaFeber">Walter LaFeber</a> said that the incident made some 'reticent Americans' realise the <a href="Power%20%28international%20relations%29">power</a> implications of expansion in the South Pacific.
